comment.body:
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has been open for 4 days with no activity.
Unfortunately, our resources are limited and we can not always take the time to respond to requests about websites that are not popular enough. The issue will be closed if no further activity occurs.
Please note, that AdGuard Filters is an open-source project that is used by different content blockers and we welcome contributions. If you have some technical knowledge about how websites work, you are welcome to create a pull request following [these instructions](https://github.com/AdguardTeam/AdguardFilters/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).

comment.body:
Not reproduced with AdGuard filters on my end.
Try to leave only AdGuard filters below, update them (wait almost one minute there), clear browser data, restart it, open the site.
If that doesn't work, you should re-enable the content blockers in Safari settings (wait about the same time as when you update the filters).
```
AdGuard Base
AdGuard Tracking Protection
AdGuard Cookie Notices
AdGuard Popups
AdGuard Mobile App Banners
AdGuard Other Annoyances
AdGuard Widgets
```

issue.title: Potential Solution for Peacock Ads

labels.name: A: In progress
labels.description: Work on the issue is in progress

labels.name: A: Waiting for data
labels.description: Waiting for more information from the user

issue.body:
### Prerequisites

- [x] I checked the documentation and found no answer;
- [x] I checked to make sure that this issue has not already been filed;
- [x] This is not an ad/bug report.

### Problem description

Ads have recently started making their way through Peacock, and seem to have been for many users.

### Proposed solution

The following rules have successfully blocked all ads on Peacock (so far):
```
||g*-vod-us-cmaf-prd-*.cdn.peacocktv.com  # blocks all ads
@@||g*-vod-us-cmaf-prd-mc.cdn.peacocktv.com  # seems to allow the main content to come through.
```

Would love some feedback on if this works for anyone else.

### Additional information

Thanks to [this list of domains](https://gist.github.com/ozankiratli/801ba17705e7f2a904d2e443af5a64f8#peacock) curated by @ozankiratli as the base of this solution.

labels.description: Work on the issue is in progress

issue.body:
### Prerequisites

- [x] This site DOES NOT contain sexually explicit material, otherwise use [NSFW-specific form](./new?template=bug_report_NSFW.yml);
- [x] Filters were updated before reproducing an issue;
- [x] AdGuard product version is up-to-date;
- [x] Browser version is up-to-date;
- [x] If the site or app is broken, disabling AdGuard protection resolves an issue.

### What product do you use?

AdGuard for Windows

### AdGuard version

7.20.3

### What type of problem have you encountered?

Missed analytics or tracker

### Which browser(s) do you use?

Firefox

### Which device do you use?

Desktop

### Where is the problem encountered?

https://www.coupang.com/

### Ad Blocking

AdGuard Base filter

### Privacy

_No response_

### Social Widgets

_No response_

### Annoyances

_No response_

### Security

_No response_

### Other

_No response_

### DNS filters

_No response_

### Language-specific

_No response_

### What Stealth Mode options do you have enabled?

_No response_

### Add your comment and screenshots

`https://www.coupang.com/OWHDBB6L/6ouh-rX/kOocuaA/nH/5G1ztGNG5ENm8S3XDi/GQ41Sg5kMgI/Oy/l4fgYQcyA`
`https://www.coupang.com/OWHDBB6L/6ouh-rX/kOocuaA/nH/rp1ztGVE5EfO/AxM7Sg5kMgI/Gj/sJa1IjGUE6AQ?v=9ec43e58-aeff-c999-4134-4bbbff831731`

Cookies:
```
trac_addtag
trac_ctag
trac_itime
trac_lptag
trac_spec
trac_src
clickCoach
x-coupang-target-market
```

Coupang `Security Connection Failure Error` Resolution Rules
`@@||coupang.com^$stealth=useragent`



### Privacy

- [x] I agree to follow this condition

comment.body: I'm not sure about blocking the requests and the cookie `x-coupang-target-market`. I also don't see the cookies `trac_`, `clickCoach` on my end. @piquark6046 could you also check this on your side?

issue.title: rjotswpm.rukuten.com

labels.name: A: In progress
labels.description: Work on the issue is in progress

issue.body:
### Issue URL (Annoyance) [https://rjotswpm.rukuten.com](https://adguardteam.github.io/AnonymousRedirect/redirect.html?url=https%3A%2F%2Frjotswpm.rukuten.com) ### Comment > I need a favour from you guys. > > I'm much too (young|old) to handle things like https://github.com/DandelionSprout/adfilt/issues/1165 being more concerned about his company's market value or something like that than on anything else, especially things like not *entirely* realising how nasty that domain parking services (which are apparently among his customers) can be in regards to malware redirections. > > **But** he has convinced me about 1 thing, which is that a lot of the entries I have/had for his company in Dandelion Sprout's Anti-Malware List are not malware. > > I see there's precedence in AdGuard Tracking Protection Filter for blocking `||youseasky.com^`, which I can assure you is a good entry; but based on the wider patterns on https://urlscan.io/search/#page.ip:%2254.75.69.192%22, I propose 2 entries for AdGuard Tracking Protection Filter: > ``` > ://euob.*.com/sxp^$script,3p > ://obseu.*.com/sxp^$script,3p > ``` > You guys have probably been in many more such cases than me, so I'm more or less leaving this up to you guys. ``` Username: @DandelionSprout ``` ### Screenshots
Screenshot 1 ![Screenshot 1](https://cdn.adguard.info/sitereports/gh2tmjenwhwgs4kkscgosk8k0c00wok8jkxp87zfl8.png?nc=1)
### System configuration Information | Value --- | --- Platform: | uBlock Origin v1.64.1b4 System version: | `Windows 11 24H2 with all monthly updates through June-ish 2025` Browser: | Vivaldi Filters: | Ad blocking:
AdGuard Base,
EasyList

Privacy:
AdGuard Tracking Protection,
Legitimate URL Shortener

Annoyances:
AdGuard Cookie Notices,
AdGuard Popups

Security:
Online Malicious URL Blocklist,
uBlock Origin – Badware risks

Language-specific:
EasyList Lithuania,
Dandelion Sprout's Serbo-Croatian List,
Dandelion Sprout's Nordic Filters,
Adblock List for Finland Custom filters: | `uBlock Filters (Ads, Quick fixes, Unbreak, Cookie Notices, Annoyances)`,
`Bypass Paywalls Clean Filter`,
`EasyList Notifications (uBO's version)`,
`Fanboy's Agegate List`,
`Block Outsider Intrusion into LAN`,
`https://raw.githubusercontent.com/DandelionSprout/adfilt/master/AntiMV3List.txt`,
`https://raw.githubusercontent.com/DandelionSprout/adfilt2/main/AntiCartoonHipsterList.txt` Other extensions used: | `Bitwarden, Redirector`

comment.body:
I'm not sure it's worth deleting the rule. It collects data, especially without asking. This does not contradict our filter policy. At the same time, I don't see how this benefits a visitor who accidentally visits such a site.
I think these scripts are just used to collect analytics.

issue.title: rjotswpm.rukuten.com
issue.body:
### Issue URL (Annoyance) [https://rjotswpm.rukuten.com](https://adguardteam.github.io/AnonymousRedirect/redirect.html?url=https%3A%2F%2Frjotswpm.rukuten.com) ### Comment > I need a favour from you guys. > > I'm much too (young|old) to handle things like https://github.com/DandelionSprout/adfilt/issues/1165 being more concerned about his company's market value or something like that than on anything else, especially things like not *entirely* realising how nasty that domain parking services (which are apparently among his customers) can be in regards to malware redirections. > > **But** he has convinced me about 1 thing, which is that a lot of the entries I have/had for his company in Dandelion Sprout's Anti-Malware List are not malware. > > I see there's precedence in AdGuard Tracking Protection Filter for blocking `||youseasky.com^`, which I can assure you is a good entry; but based on the wider patterns on https://urlscan.io/search/#page.ip:%2254.75.69.192%22, I propose 2 entries for AdGuard Tracking Protection Filter: > ``` > ://euob.*.com/sxp^$script,3p > ://obseu.*.com/sxp^$script,3p > ``` > You guys have probably been in many more such cases than me, so I'm more or less leaving this up to you guys. ``` Username: @DandelionSprout ``` ### Screenshots
Screenshot 1 ![Screenshot 1](https://cdn.adguard.info/sitereports/gh2tmjenwhwgs4kkscgosk8k0c00wok8jkxp87zfl8.png?nc=1)

comment.body:
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has been open for 4 days with no activity.
Unfortunately, our resources are limited and we can not always take the time to respond to requests about websites that are not popular enough. The issue will be closed if no further activity occurs.
Please note, that AdGuard Filters is an open-source project that is used by different content blockers and we welcome contributions. If you have some technical knowledge about how websites work, you are welcome to create a pull request following [these instructions](https://github.com/AdguardTeam/AdguardFilters/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).

issue.body:

- [x] This site DOES NOT contain sexually explicit material, otherwise use [NSFW-specific form](./new?template=bug_report_NSFW.yml);
- [x] Filters were updated before reproducing an issue;
- [x] AdGuard product version is up-to-date;
- [x] Browser version is up-to-date;
- [x] If the site or app is broken, disabling AdGuard protection resolves an issue.

### What product do you use?

AdGuard for Windows

7.20.3

### What type of problem have you encountered?

Missed analytics or tracker

Firefox

Desktop

https://www.coupang.com/

comment.body:
The logistics behind my plan was that if an entry sounded like it could be made generic, then it'd be worth it to make it generic.

For example, to take entirely random made-up examples, something like `##.johnmadden-rex-grande-cookiedeal` sounds to me personally like it wouldn't cause problems on other sites, whereas something like `##.cookiebanner` would've caused problems.

comment.body:
@Alex-302 I'd like to provide more context for your consideration. 

1. My point on the other thread was that we serve over 15,000 customers. Most are not engaging in anything `nasty`, on the contrary (  I am willing to provide a sample of our customers in private for your reference ).   Blocking our domain using a regex harms not only those engaging in `nasty` activities, but reduces the **value** we provide to all. 
2. Our tag is not facilitating or acting as a vector to spread malware / tracking / annoyance.   In the example [https://rjotswpm.rukuten.com](https://adguardteam.github.io/AnonymousRedirect/redirect.html?url=https%3A%2F%2Frjotswpm.rukuten.com)  it might be used in a site that is considered an annoyance.
But it does not facilitate that activity whatsoever.  It does not spread malware, it does not track, it does not manipulate the page or create pop ups, it does no activity which can be considered as harmful and cannot be used by any customer as such.   All it does is measures whether a page visit was done by a real / automatic session. 


The inclusion of `/sxp/i/*$script,third-party` effectively hinders our tag completely.   Is there a way to either 
1. prove and provide evidence on our usecase to you.
2. If not, limit the scope in such a way that only speicifc tag domains (  limited to the "offending"  customer) will be added

### Issue URL (Annoyance) [https://rjotswpm.rukuten.com](https://adguardteam.github.io/AnonymousRedirect/redirect.html?url=https%3A%2F%2Frjotswpm.rukuten.com) ### Comment > I need a favour from you guys. > > I'm much too (young|old) to handle things like https://github.com/DandelionSprout/adfilt/issues/1165 being more concerned about his company's market value or something like that than on anything else, especially things like not *entirely* realising how nasty that domain parking services (which are apparently among his customers) can be in regards to malware redirections. > > **But** he has convinced me about 1 thing, which is that a lot of the entries I have/had for his company in Dandelion Sprout's Anti-Malware List are not malware. > > I see there's precedence in AdGuard Tracking Protection Filter for blocking `||youseasky.com^`, which I can assure you is a good entry; but based on the wider patterns on https://urlscan.io/search/#page.ip:%2254.75.69.192%22, I propose 2 entries for AdGuard Tracking Protection Filter: > ``` > ://euob.*.com/sxp^$script,3p > ://obseu.*.com/sxp^$script,3p > ``` > You guys have probably been in many more such cases than me, so I'm more or less leaving this up to you guys. ``` Username: @DandelionSprout ``` ### Screenshots

comment.body:
The code is heavily obfuscated. Although this is not a criterion for blocking, it looks suspicious.
A large amount of data (about equipment, behaviour, UTM and similar query params) is collected, apparently there is integration with popular analytics systems.

If the purpose of the script is to protect (which side?), what prevents an attacker from blocking it? What is the point of adding it, especially on websites that are for sale?

issue.title: www.itpassportsiken.com
issue.body:
### Issue URL (Social Widget) [https://www.itpassportsiken.com/s/kakomon/02_aki/q4.html](https://adguardteam.github.io/AnonymousRedirect/redirect.html?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.itpassportsiken.com%2Fs%2Fkakomon%2F02_aki%2Fq4.html) ### Comment > - Block rule is not being applied correctly. > > There is a generic rule `##.social-btn-list_mini` in the social filter. This rule should hide the share buttons on this website, but it's not functioning correctly. > Suspecting it might be an iOS bug, I updated the rule and waited 2 minutes after the update, but nothing changed. This led me to suspect it's an app bug rather than an iOS bug. > > I checked several websites where elements should be hidden by the same rule. I found that the rule works correctly on those websites. This means the rule is loaded and functioning, but it's not working only on certain websites. > > Here are the websites I tested: > > [Not working] > https://fp3-siken.com/kakomon/2021_9/20.html > https://fp2-siken.com/kakomon/2023_9/05.html > https://fp1-siken.com/kakomon/2025_1/05.html > https://www.sc-siken.com/kakomon/05_aki/am2_22.html > https://www.fe-siken.com/kakomon/25_aki/q5.html > https://www.ap-siken.com/kakomon/28_haru/q5.html > https://www.db-siken.com/kakomon/05_aki/am2_1.html > https://www.pm-siken.com/s/kakomon/03_aki/am1_29.html > https://www.nw-siken.com/s/kakomon/04_haru/am1_5.html > https://www.sg-siken.com/kakomon/30_aki/q1.html > > [Working correctly] > https://takken-siken.com/kakomon/2020-1/18.html > https://chintaikanrishi-siken.com/kakomon/2020/36.html > https://denkou2-siken.com/kakomon/2022_1-am/13.html > https://kangyou-siken.com/kakomon/2020/06.html > > > I'm not sure whether this is a rule bug, iOS bug, or app bug. ### Issue URL (Social Widget) [https://www.itpassportsiken.com/s/kakomon/02_aki/q4.html](https://adguardteam.github.io/AnonymousRedirect/redirect.html?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.itpassportsiken.com%2Fs%2Fkakomon%2F02_aki%2Fq4.html) ### Comment > - Block rule is not being applied correctly. > > There is a generic rule `##.social-btn-list_mini` in the social filter. This rule should hide the share buttons on this website, but it's not functioning correctly. > Suspecting it might be an iOS bug, I updated the rule and waited 2 minutes after the update, but nothing changed. This led me to suspect it's an app bug rather than an iOS bug. > > I checked several websites where elements should be hidden by the same rule. I found that the rule works correctly on those websites. This means the rule is loaded and functioning, but it's not working only on certain websites. > > Here are the websites I tested: > > [Not working] > https://fp3-siken.com/kakomon/2021_9/20.html > https://fp2-siken.com/kakomon/2023_9/05.html > https://fp1-siken.com/kakomon/2025_1/05.html > https://www.sc-siken.com/kakomon/05_aki/am2_22.html > https://www.fe-siken.com/kakomon/25_aki/q5.html > https://www.ap-siken.com/kakomon/28_haru/q5.html > https://www.db-siken.com/kakomon/05_aki/am2_1.html > https://www.pm-siken.com/s/kakomon/03_aki/am1_29.html > https://www.nw-siken.com/s/kakomon/04_haru/am1_5.html > https://www.sg-siken.com/kakomon/30_aki/q1.html > > [Working correctly] > https://takken-siken.com/kakomon/2020-1/18.html > https://chintaikanrishi-siken.com/kakomon/2020/36.html > https://denkou2-siken.com/kakomon/2022_1-am/13.html > https://kangyou-siken.com/kakomon/2020/06.html > > > I'm not sure whether this is a rule bug, iOS bug, or app bug. comment.body:
I'll be happy to answer -

1. the code is obfuscated in order to make reverse engineering more difficult.  As you correctly assumed - an attacker can also block it, that's why we use a layered approach - for customers who are willing to install us also on server side, we can detect and block using server side methods.   the JS is running additional tests.  And in order to mitigate (  but unfortunately this cannot be 0%  ) the attacker attempts, we obfuscate it.

2. We have integrations to SIEMs / data wharehouses / data lakes / and analytical systems.   Our customers might prefer one or the other depending on what they know and have.   Data attributes are an extension of `automatic session / human`

3. All our customers are paid customers.   Some are large enterprises, and some are in the adtech business. Some Adtech customers might use us on parked domains.  I understand the concerns you have regarding parked domains, however the customer's dont always have control on where they are placed,  and even if they do , it is not strictly non legitimate.   All I'm asking is that in case you do find it illegitimate, at the very list block the explicit JS domain the customer uses.  In this manner other customers who have done nothing wrong will not be impacted.

4. We collect data only in what data can help us to detect illegitimate traffic. We do not use it to track users what so ever.
